1 ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 133-148 APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL Catalysts derived from polymer-stabilised colloidal platinum: Effects of support and calcination on the catalytic behaviour in hydrogenation D.G. Duff 1, T. Mallat, M. Schneider, A. Baiker * Department of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH-Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland Received 23 May 1995; accepted 16 July 1995 Abstract Platinum colloids prepared by reduction of H2PtC16 with methanol in the presence of polyvinyl- pyrrolidone have been examined in the sol state and following immobilisation on oxide supports. Both the sol and the supported catalysts contained platinum metal particles of 3--4 nm number-mean diameter, as determined by TEM. High initial activities for hydrogenation of the medium-sized alkenes trans-stilbene and methylcinnamate were recorded. The platinum particles were compared for particle size distribution and catalytic activity in the unsupported (sol) state and in supported states, both before and after heat treatment in oxygen-argon at 300 (calcination). Highest activities were measured for the sol state and for the calcined supported catalysts. It is suggested that this behaviour is related to the influence of support and polymer on the accessibility of the metal surface for the reactants. Marked activity differences between a platinum-colloid catalyst immobilised on a titania aerogel and a binary Pt-titania aerogel, directly prepared by a one-step sol-gel route with ensuing supercritical drying, are discussed. Keywords: Hydrogenation; Alkene; Platinum; Colloid; Sol; lmmobilisation; Heterogenisation; Aerogel I. Introduction Catalysis by metal nanoparticles prepared by colloidal routes has been the subject of intermittent research for several decades [ 1,2 ]. An important milestone was the * Corresponding author. E-mail baiker@tech.chem.ethz.ch, tel. ( +41-1 ) 6323153, fax ( +41-1 ) 6321163. Duff et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 133-148 work of Nord and co-workers in the 1940's and 50's [3,4], who were the first to prepare noble metal colloids stabilised by synthetic polymers and examine the catalytic properties. In a proportion of cases the metal colloids have been immo- bilised on support [5-27], thus giving the advantages of a truly heterogeneous catalytic system. Subsequent heat treatment to diminish the amount of residues from the organic colloid stabilisers has only relatively rarely been employed [5- 8,11,19-22]. In no previous work known to the authors have the effects of this immobilisation and subsequent calcination on the catalytic activity and particle size distribution been systematically investigated. The present paper attempts to compare the catalytic performance of colloidal platinum particles from the same dispersion in a variety of different environments. In a previous work [ 28] the direct preparation of binary Pt-titania aerogels via a sol-gel route with subsequent supercritical drying was investigated. The platinum nanoparticles formed in situ were uniformly distributed and partially occluded in the highly porous titania aerogel matrix. In the present work the alternative approach of synthesising the particles in colloid form and then bringing them onto titania aerogel (and other supports of high surface area) when already formed has been examined. The use of nanocrystalline supports also facilitates the identification of supported metal particles in the TEM images and allows subtle changes in size distribution to be detected. The liquid phase hydrogenations of trans-stilbene ( 1 ) and methylcinnamate (2) were chosen for the characterization of the accessibility and activity of the platinum particles: Ph-CH=CH-Ph + H2 --> Ph-H2-H2-Ph ( 1 ) Ph-CH=CH-COOCH3 + H2 ~ Ph-CHz--CH2-COOCH3 (2) 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation and characterization of the catalysts The metal sol (colloidal dispersion) in methanol was prepared according to a method adapted from that of Hirai [29]. Chloroplatinic acid (H2PtC16), polyvi- nylpyrrolidone (PVP-k30), purum, of about 40 000 mean molecular weight and analytical grade methanol (Fluka) were used as received without further purifica- tion. PVP (750 mg) was dissolved in a volume ( 100 ml) of methanol with stirring until the solution was quite clear. Chloroplatinic acid (83 mg) was dissolved in methanol ( 10 ml) and this was added to the PVP solution with stirring and washed in with a further 125 ml methanol. Although no water was added, traces will be present due to the water of crystallisation of the platinum(IV) complex together with that present in the hygroscopic polymer and methanol. The solution was then D.G. Duff et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 133-148 135 heated to boiling under continuous nitrogen flow and boiled under reflux for 90 min. About 20 min after commencement of boiling the colour of the solution changed suddenly to dark brown as the platinum colloids formed. Two batches of sol were performed by the same, above method -- they will be described as sols Ptl and Pt2. The sols were characterised using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) as well as UV-VIS extinction measurements. For diffraction-contrast TEM measurements particles from the sol were sup- ported on a carbon film by allowing a drop of the methanol-diluted sol to contact the film for a few seconds. A Hitachi H-600 operated at 100 kV was employed, providing intermediate resolution corresponding to an information limit of about 0.3 nm. Particle size distributions were obtained by measurement of equivalent circle diameters of well-focused Pt particles. In all cases measurements from a series of exposures (at least six) of different areas of sample were made, compared and combined to give a particle size distribution, PSD. The measurements from n Pt particles were analyzed to yield (number-)mean particle diameter, (d), and the coefficient of variation (c.v.; standard deviation of the distribution as a percent fraction of the mean). The PSDs also yielded the mass- (volume-) weighted mean, (d)vwt and the surface/volume ratio for the particles, SA/V. UV-VIS spectra were acquired at wavelengths between 800 and 200 nm of samples in quartz cells ( 1 mm path length) employing a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 16 spectrophotorneter. To prepare a heterogeneous catalyst, a volume of sol was mixed with a methanolic suspension of a high-surface-area oxide support (alumina or titania) which had been exposed to low-energy ultrasonic irradiation to improve the dispersion of the powder in the solvent. In this case no adjustment of the pH was necessary. The amounts were chosen to give a 2% Pt by weight catalyst calculated on a Pt/ (Pt + support) basis. After ca. 5 min the supported catalyst was filtered off through a 0.45/xm nylon filter membrane (Whatman) and washed twice on the membrane with 50 ml volumes of methanol. The filtrates were in every case colourless, indicating (near-) quantitative adhesion of platinum particles to the support as well as the absence of significant quantities of unreduced, unadsorbed ions. The loading was independently confirmed by ICP-AES. The supports used were a titania (ana- tase, ca. 200 m2 g- ~) prepared by the sol-gel-aerogel route described in Ref. [ 30] as well as the commercial oxides aluminium oxide 'C' (alumina, ca. 100 m2 g-J; Degussa) and titania P25 (mixture of rutile and anatase, ca. 60 m2 g- 1; Degussa). The samples were then dried overnight under reduced pressure at 110. According to the support the abbreviations -aer (aerogel titania), -alox (alumina 'C' ) and - P25 are attached to the name of the parent sol, Ptl or Pt2, to identify the solid catalyst samples. The catalysts were characterised using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) before and after calcination, which consisted of temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) coupled to a mass spectrometer (Balzers, QMG420 with QMA120), thus 136 D.G. Duffer al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 133-148 allowing the calcination process to be performed and monitored in situ, as well as by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). For the TEM measurements specimens were prepared simply by dusting a carbon film with the catalyst powder in its dry form, thus avoiding artefacts associated with the resuspension into a liquid [ 31 ]. Dif- fraction-contrast TEM analysis of these specimens was carried out and evaluated as described for the sols. High-resolution (phase-contrast) TEM images were obtained by means of a Philips CM30ST electron microscope at 300 kV, with a point resolution of 0.19 nm. Powder XRD was performed using a Siemens 0/0 D5000 powder diffractometer. The diffractograms were recorded with Cu Ka radiation over a 20 range 20-80and a position-sensitive detector with Ni-filter. The measuring time was 30 s per degree 20. In the calcination step (TPO) first argon and then a mixture of oxygen and argon (7% 02 in Ar) was led through the sample with a gas hourly space velocity of about 8 000 h- ~. While under Ar flow the sample was heated at a rate of 5 K min- 1 to 300 where it was held for 1 h. It was then cooled to 50, the gas switched to 7% 02 in Ar, and reheated at 5 K min- ~ to 300, where it this time stayed for 5 h before cooling. Samples prepared from Pt2 were additionally characterized by microanalysis for the elements C, H, N before and after calcination. 2.2. Hydrogenation reactions The reactions were performed in a 150 ml, flat-bottomed glass batch reactor (D = 75 mm) equipped with gas inlet and outlet, condenser, and thermometer. The mixing frequency of the magnetic stirrer was 1000 min- 1; the length of the magnetic rod was 50 mm. Trans-stilbene was hydrogenated in isopropylacetate, at 33, and methylcinnamate in methanol, at 0. The hydrogen flow-rate (30 ml min-1, ambient pressure) was measured by a rotameter. At first 10-50 mg catalyst was prehydrogenated in 30 ml solvent. After 15 min an amount (2 mmol) of reactant in 10 ml solvent was injected. Samples of the reaction mixture were periodically taken, filtered and analyzed with a gas chromatograph, using a HP-20M wide-pore capillary column operated between 130 and 220, with a helium carrier-gas flow- rate of 40 ml rain- t and a split ratio of 11. Initial rates were determined from the consumption of the reactant at below 5% conversion by linear fitting (R ~> 0.999). The reaction rate was independent of the catalyst amount ( ~< 50 mg) and mixing speed ( ~> 1000 rpm) showing that intra- reactor and inter-particle mass transfer is not influential. Under the same conditions the specific catalytic activity of an Engelhard 5-wt.-% Pt/alumina catalyst ( E7004 ) was measured as a reference (E7004; metal dispersion ca. 0.3 determined by TEM -- polydispersity and electron opaque support did not allow an accurate determi- nation of the Pt particle size). As a further comparison this catalyst (700 mg) was suspended in methanol (200 ml) containing dissolved PVP (300 mg). After drying as above, the catalytic D.G. Results 3.1. Platinum particle size and structure The TEM results showed the sols Ptl and Pt2 to consist of well-separated, near spherical nanoparticles (e.g., Fig. lb). Comparing the data in Table 1 we see that sol Pt2 has slightly higher dispersity than sol Ptl. From the c.v. values ( 14-31% ) we see that the systems are very monodisperse compared with many catalysts but rather typical for Pt sols. Analysis of the UV-VIS spectra according to the method of Furlong and co-workers [32-34] yields values of the gradient log(extinction/ units)/log(wavelength/units) of - 3.2 and - 2.9 for sols Ptl and Pt2, respectively; values near three have been shown for aqueous methanolic platinum dispersions to indicate well-dispersed sols of nearly spherical particles [ 34]. This empirical rela- tionship helps to confirm the representative nature of the TEM images. The TEM images of uncalcined catalyst Ptl-P25 show that the particles have adsorbed in a controlled, well-separated manner onto the support (Fig. 1 c). From Table 1 it is apparent that in the uncalcined catalysts there has been little change in the measured size distribution as compared to that for the sol. Upon calcination of Ptl-P25 there does seem to be a slight increase in <d>, from 3.5 nm to 3.9 nm. ( For Pt 1 -aer the statistical sample size is too small for accurate determination). However, as demonstrated by the micrograph (Fig. ld) the catalyst remains well dispersed on the support following heat treatment. Comparison of the particle size distributions (PSD) for the system Ptl-P25 (Fig. 2) shows that very little change in size distribution occurs between the sol and the uncalcined supported catalyst, but that heat treatment seems to remove a proportion of the smallest particles. For sol Pt2 (Table 1) the calcined catalysts again show a small increase in particle size with respect to the original sol, once again of 0.3 to 0.4 nm in < d>. The PSDs (Fig. 3) again show a disappearance of a proportion of the smallest particles and (less pronounced) the appearance of a few larger species. All these very small changes in PSD are more or less on the border of experimental error. The XRD powder patterns of the catalysts Pt 1-aer and Pt2-alox are shown in Fig. 4 together with the patterns of the pure titania and alumina. Subtraction of the support pattern yielded broad reflections for metallic Pt in all cases and was most successful for Pt2-alox. For this catalyst, in the region of the { 111 } reflection of metallic platinum, a simple Scherrer analysis of the peak resulted in (volume- weighted) average crystallite sizes of 2.4 and 2.6 nm for the uncalcined and calcined catalysts, respectively. More refined subtraction and Debye Function analysis [ 35 ] would have been needed to interpret fully the patterns, but here the Pt concentration is rather small. HREM images of the catalyst Ptl-aer (Fig. 5) show that the Pt particles, where lattice fringes are present, show structures consistent with single crystalline or singly twinned face-centred-cubic particles. 3.2. Organic residues Contamination of the catalyst by organic residues following preparation will be largely due to the sheaths of polyvinylpyrrolidone around the platinum surfaces which stabilise the colloidal particles in sol. To a lesser extent, alkoxylation of support-bound hydroxyl groups, some organic oxidation products (precursor reduc- tion), and organic species catalytically decomposed on the Pt surface must also be taken into account [ 28 ]. An estimation of the extent of organic residues remaining in the solid catalysts and the efficiency of its removal upon calcination was per- formed in two ways: (i) Examination of the percentages of C, H and N in the catalyst both before and after heat-treatment, provided by elemental microanalysis; (ii) Monitoring the evolution of oxidation products of organic molecules during calcination using mass spectrometry. The results of the chemical analyses on samples prepared from sol Pt2 are presented (Table 2). The organic residues (carbon content) decrease upon calcin- ing, but only by factors of 3 (Pt2-alox) and 17 ( Pt2-P25 ). If all the polymer present in the sol had been retained in the uncalcined catalysts (and neglecting any chloride, methanol or water present), the analysis values would have been of the order of 20 and 4 wt.-%, considerably higher than actually found for the raw catalysts. Catalyst preparation and characterization The two sol preparations Ptl and Pt2 delivered slightly different particle size distributions (PSD), as is evident from Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 and Table 1. The mech- anism of formation and possible reasons for scatter in particle size in a related system have been extensively discussed elsewhere [34]. The width of the size distribution, 14 < c.v. < 31%, is larger than for two extremely monodisperse colloid preparations of c.v. = 10%, polyoxoanion-stabilised Ir at about 2 nm [25,26] and citrate-stabilised Au at e.g. 14 nm [36] ; these latter two preparations are among the most monodisperse forms of divided metal ( > 1 nm) for which particle size distribution information has been published. The crystal structure of the colloids and apparent absence of multiply twinned particles are typical for small platinum particles [ 37 ]. The extremely approximate crystallite diameter values from XRD are not far from the TEM-particle diameters, also indicating a high degree of crystallinity, but the data are insufficient for a firm conclusion. The immobilisation of the particles onto supports probably follows the principle of heterocoagulation of oppositely charged particles as demonstrated for gold clus- D.G. This method of supporting metal colloids from aqueous dispersion has been known for a long time [39]. Methanol, like water, is a protic solvent of reasonable dielectric constant, facilitating the existence of charged surfaces, so electrostatic interactions should also play an important role in the present methan- olic system. Methanol was chosen over water as the dispersion medium for the platinum sol because of its lower capillary forces/surface tension, which should lessen the structure collapse of the porous supports upon drying [40]. 4.2. Catalyst calcination and contamination From the elemental microanalysis values it emerges that around 90% of the PVP initially present is removed from the catalyst upon filtering and washing. Since dilution is usually inefficient at removing adsorbed polymer in the absence of a competitive adsorber or displacer [41,42], this suggests that 90% of the polymer is in fact not bound to the surface of the platinum or the oxide after mixing sols of metal and support. Moreover, excess free polymer is also known to increase the final stability of a dispersion by the mechanism of depletion stabilisation, as seen for PVP with titanium dioxide pigments [43]. After calcination the sample supported on alumina, Pt2-alox, retains more organic residues than does Pt2-P25. This may be due to different pore structures of the two supports and/or the different adsorption strength and capacity of the nitro- gen-containing polymer (different acidities and specific surface areas of the sup- ports), which might be indicated by the different nitrogen contents (Table 2). In each case examination of the ion intensities (m/z=44, 28) showed that further calcination at 300 would have been relatively ineffective in decreasing the organic content. 4.3. Catalyst performance All the samples are active for the hydrogenation of both medium-sized alkenes. The catalytic activities of the two sols Ptl and Pt2 (Table 3) are more different than one would expect based on their specific surface areas (Table 1 ). The reason for this is not yet known. The presence of systems with very similar metal PSDs allows the effect of environment of the metal particles to be examined. The marked change in activities upon supporting and calcining the metal particles can be explained as follows: (i) Sol: high activity. (iii) Calcined catalyst: activity higher again. Accessibility of the Pt surface for the organic reactants is enhanced through removal by oxidation of PVP from the particle surfaces. With trans-stilbene hydrogenation, the deactivation of the most active catalysts may be by virtue of alkene polymerisation in the presence of oxidised but not fully removed organic residues and/or acidic supports. The striking similarity of the PSDs of Ptl-aer and Pt2PC, a Pt-titania aerogel from a previous work [28] prepared by a one-step method, allows an interesting comparison (Table 4). Both contain 2 wt.-% Pt derived from chloroplatinum precursors. The titania support [ 30] of Ptl-aer is prepared by similar means to the titania matrix of the binary Pt2PC aerogel. In both cases the crystalline fractions of titania consist of well-developed anatase crystallites and the textural properties are almost identical [ 28,30]. In Pt2PC the metal particles are formed in situ from PtC14 dissolved in MeOH-H20 together with the titania matrix during supercritical dry- ing. Methanol is the solvent in both cases. The catalytic activities for the hydro- genation oftrans-stilbene under almost identical conditions are, however, markedly different (Table 4). The supported colloid sample is 3-4 times more active after calcination than the one-step sample (Table 4). Pt2PC, prepared without PVP present, does not show the marked rise in catalytic activity after oxidative heat treatment at 300 (this time in air) that the immobilised Ptl and Pt2 samples exhibit. This difference in the activities probably reflects the different accessibility of the platinum particles for medium-large reactants in each case. With the sol method the metal particles at coverage lower than saturation will preferentially stick to well exposed areas of support and can not in any case penetrate into the smaller pores. A high proportion of the metal surface is thus accessible for the reactants. By contrast in the case of the one-step preparations the metal particles are very homo- geneously distributed and partially occluded in a highly porous titania aerogel matrix [28]. Although resulting in a lower specific activity, this aspect favours both thermal and abrasive stability for the one-step systems [28]. Further investi- D.G. Baiker ∗ Department of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH-Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland ∗ Corresponding author. Tel. (+41-1) 6323153, fax (+41-1) 6321163. 1 Present address: Bayer AG, Central Research Department, ZF-TTP1 Interface Physics, D-51368 Leverkusen, Germany. Platinum colloids prepared by reduction of H2PtCl6 with methanol in the presence of polyvinylpyrrolidone have been examined in the sol state and following immobilisation on oxide supports. Both the sol and the supported catalysts contained platinum metal particles of 3–4 nm number-mean diameter, as determined by TEM. High initial activities for hydrogenation of the medium-sized alkenes trans-stilbene and methylcinnamate were recorded. The platinum particles were compared for particle size distribution and catalytic activity in the unsupported (sol) state and in supported states, both before and after heat treatment in oxygen-argon at 300°C (calcination). Highest activities were measured for the sol state and for the calcined supported catalysts. It is suggested that this behaviour is related to the influence of support and polymer on the accessibility of the metal surface for the reactants. Marked activity differences between a platinum-colloid catalyst immobilised on a titania aerogel and a binary Pt-titania aerogel, directly prepared by a one-step sol-gel route with ensuing supercritical drying, are discussed.
